Review: What Maisie Knew

By James Bithell

This modern reworking of Henry James' 1897 novel presents a touching insight into a broken family, from the perspective of a seven-year-old girl. James Lovatt reviews.

Ben Affleck: the right choice for Batman?

By James Bithell

Warner Bros. have confirmed that the <em>Daredevil</em> star will join Henry Cavill in Zack Snyder's <em>Batman vs. Superman</em>, set for 2015. After trepidation from fans, James Lovatt looks at whether he's the right man for the role.

Review: The Lone Ranger

By James Bithell

Ignore the States; The Lone Ranger is a good old corny popcorn movie. Maddy Breen reviews.

Top five films for Freshers' Week

Freshers' Week isn't all about alcohol fuelled madness. For those nights spent in your PJs, George Wood has put together his list of top films to get your flat together.

Review: Like Someone In Love

By James Bithell

Abbas Kiarostami latest feature is a beautifully shot and intricately plotted slow burner. Sepehr Gohardani reviews.

Review: Foxfire

By James Bithell

Laurent Cantet's English language debut and follow up to 2008's Palme d'Or winning The Class fails to translate. James Tyas reviews.

Review: Alan Partridge: Alpha Papa

By James Bithell

The transition onto the silver screen isn't entirely seamless, but there are enough classic Partridgeisms to appeal to fans both old and new.

Review: Frances Ha

By James Bithell

Greta Gerwig finds her name bandied about as a potential Oscar winner for this impeccable performance of friendship, identity and independence.

Review: The Heat

By James Bithell

The Heat won't win any prizes for originality, but Sandra Bullock and Melissa McCarthy impress in this slightly flimsy buddy cop comedy. James Tyas reviews.

Review: Only God Forgives

By James Bithell

Nicolas Winding Refn's divisive follow up to 2011's Drive is thrilling and uncompromising but to the detriment of an enjoyable cinematic experience. George Wood reviews.

Upcoming Distractions: Weekly Trailer Round-up

James Tyas takes a looks at the best and worst of the week's trailers. Includes Romeo and Juliet, American Hustle, The Secret Life of Walter Mitty and Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa.

Review: Wadjda

By James Bithell

Wadjda, the first film directed by a Saudi woman, is funny, tender and surprisingly uplifting. Rosemary Collins reviews.

Review: The Wolverine

By James Bithell

The Wolverine's attempt to appeal to both hardcore Marvel fans and the more casual viewer yields mixed results. Sepehr Gohardani reviews.

Review: The Frozen Ground

By James Bithell

For what The Frozen Ground lacks in originality, it makes up with uniformly great performances . Sepehr Gohardani reviews.

Review: The Bling Ring

By James Bithell

Sofia Coppola's crime drama revels in Hollywood glam while being no different in tone or spectacle to your average trip to H&M. Alfie Packham reviews

Review: Pacific Rim

By James Bithell

Despite bearing a worrying resemblance to Michael Bay's Transformer series, Pacific Rim possesses a sense of fun and excitement

Review: The World's End

By James Bithell

The Cornetto Trilogy remains satisfying to the last lick with a final chapter that works well as both a parody and a sci-fi in its own right. Alfie Packham reviews

Review: We Steal Secrets: The Story of WikiLeaks

By James Bithell

A revealing and balanced documentary tells the tale of Wikileaks' rise from obscurity and fall into folly with great emotion and intelligence.

Review: Now You See Me

By James Bithell

A nonsensical plot lets down a film that could have been magic. Alfie Packham reviews

Review: Much Ado About Nothing

By James Bithell

From Superheros to Shakespeare, Joss Whedon's modern-day take on Much Ado About Nothing is both clever and charming.

Review: Before Midnight

By James Bithell

Richard Linklater's third instalment in his series following the lives of Jesse and Celine is a deeply moving character study

Review: A Field in England

By James Bithell

Ben Wheatley, one of the most prolific and critically-lauded British directors of recent years, offers up one of the most original films of the year.

Review: The Internship

By James Bithell

The stars of Wedding Crashers reunite for this comedy about two middle-aged salesmen become interns at Google. Sepehr Gohardani reviews.

Review: The Act of Killing

By James Bithell

The Act of Killing is extraordinary and it is hideous, and quite possibly the best documentary film ever made about what human beings are capable of doing to one another.

Review: Despicable Me 2

By James Bithell

Despicable Me 2 is an able and energetic sequel to its 2010 predecessor

Review: World War Z

By James Bithell

While not being the box-office flop many anticipated, Marc Forster's zombie apocalypse film is a creative failure.

First Look Review: Monsters University

By James Bithell

Monsters University is Pixar's best since Toy Story 3 but fails to step out of the shadow of its predecessor.

Murphy's Law: The art of story-telling from a BAFTA winner

BAFTA winning director Nick Murphy tells Alfie Packham about his move from TV to film, working with Paul Bettany, and offers his advice to aspiring film-makers.

Review: Behind the Candelabra

By James Bithell

Douglas gives a career best performance as an outrageously camp, preening concert pianist, allowing Soderbergh to end his career on a high. James Tyas reviews.

Have we had enough of the Superhero genre?

By James Bithell

Alfie Packham and Steven Roberts debate whether superhero franchises have run their course.

Review: What Maisie Knew

By James Bithell

This modern reworking of Henry James' 1897 novel presents a touching insight into a broken family, from the perspective of a seven-year-old girl. James Lovatt reviews.
